stem: A 28-year-old pregnant client (34 weeks gestation) presents with a severe, pounding headache and reports seeing spots (scotoma). Based on the documentation in the Obstetric Triage & Reflex Assessment tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Rule out worsening preeclampsia.
Background: G1P0. No prior history of hypertension. Symptoms started this morning.
Assessment: Client has significant facial and hand edema. Reports 2+ pitting edema in lower extremities.
Recommendation: Immediate magnesium loading dose.

tabs.title: Obstetric Triage & Reflex Assessment
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemFindingInterpretation
Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTR)4+ (Very Brisk)CNS Irritability
Ankle Clonus3 beats presentHyperreflexia
Urine Protein3+ on dipstickSignificant proteinuria
Blood Pressure168/112 mmHgSevere range

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: Blood Pressure 168/112 mmHg, Heart Rate 88 bpm, Respiratory Rate 20 breaths/min, SpO2 98%. Client reports Epigastric pain ('Heartburn').

actionOptions.text: Initiate a loading dose of Magnesium Sulfate IV
Implement seizure precautions (padded side rails, suction at bedside)
Place the client in a well-lit room to facilitate frequent assessments
Administer Furosemide to reduce peripheral edema

parameterOptions.text: Presence of epigastric pain or hepatic tenderness

rationale.correct: This client has Severe Preeclampsia (c2) and is entering the 'Impending Eclampsia' zone, evidenced by hyperreflexia (4+), clonus, scotoma, and epigastric pain (liver involvement). Priority actions are to prevent seizures via Magnesium Sulfate (a1) and protect the client from injury (a2). Parameter monitoring focuses on the CNS triggers (p1) and markers of hepatic damage (p2) which often precedes a seizure.
clinicalPearls: Epigastric pain in preeclampsia is usually a sign of liver swellingâ€”a critical warning sign.
Scotoma (spots) and headaches indicate cerebral edema/irritability.
The environment should be dark and quiet to reduce the seizure threshold.

questionTrap.trap: Auscultating fetal heart tones as the 'Priority' during an active hypertensive crisis.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While the fetus is important, the mother with hyperreflexia and a blood pressure of 168/112 mmHg will have a seizure if the magnesium isn't started. Seizure prevention is the priority.

mnemonic.title: Severe Signs
mnemonic.expansion: S-Scotoma (Spots). E-Epigastric pain. V-Very high Blood Pressure (>160 mmHg). E-Edema (Facial). R-Reflexes (4+). E-Everything's a threat (Seizure).
